author: quangtran
title: Haskell Book Japanese Translation
description: Cardano's Smart Contract is built on Haskell. But there is no book or document about Haskell for developers in Japan

f6_assessments.q0:
- The biggest barrier for project developers on the Cardano platform is the technical issue. Especially, Haskell is a difficult programming language for even those who use English as their native language.
- Japan is a potential market with many technology developers, but technical English is very limited in Japan. This makes blockchain technology enthusiasts especially the Cardano platform inaccessible to project development.
- Translating a basic book on Haskell into Japanese will motivate the blockchain-loving community in Japan to develop widely. From there, build and develop more projects on the Cardano ecosystem.
***Suggestions/ advices:
- Translation of books is just the first basic solution to help the Japanese community have more reference sources. If the proponent can combine more periodic livestreams, community care groups such as telegrams to answer readers' questions or give advice, share more learning experiences, and apply them to readers, the solution will more effective
- The proposal mentions the amount that will be shared and only shared with developer communities in Japan that the proponent knows, this number is limited. Therefore, if the proponent can publicly share this document for the Japanese community to develop the community, it will help the community to grow stronger.
f6_assessments.q1:
- The idea of the project is completely feasible and possible because the original version in English is available. It only takes a team that is good at English and Japanese to be able to do it.
- The project has a clear and specific work plan with detailed commitment numbers for each month
The team has 2 main members with skills and experience suitable for the project
- Mr. Curtis D'Alves has many years of experience with the Haskell language
-Ms.Ha has many years of experience in Japanese translation
***Suggestions/ advices:
- The translation time of 1 month is relatively short with a lot of work (370 pages of English technical language into Japanese) for 1 translator. If there is a translation team, the proposer should mention it in the team composition to increase the feasibility of the project
- If the project can name the developers in communities in Japan that the project targets, that would be great. That shows that the project has been carefully prepared and has a clear direction
- Marketing solutions have not been clearly stated. Proponents can use a number of marketing methods such as building a knowledge-sharing community on social networks, building a video channel that applies the basic knowledge in the book to make examples for readers to understand better...
f6_assessments.q2:
- The project has given the committed numbers in each month
- Provide criteria and target numbers for each criterion to evaluate the success of the project
***Suggestions/ advices:
- The numbers that the project gives are great if it can be done. But these numbers can be easily faked, one person can download many copies so if the project can come up with a solution to evaluate the actual number of downloads as well as the number of downloaders are different and are real users, people who want to use the knowledge in the book.
f6_assessments.reply:
Thank you very much for taking the time to assess our proposal

Feasibility: "The translation time of 1 month is relatively short with a lot of work (370 pages of English technical language into Japanese) for 1 translator. If there is a translation team, the proponent should mention it in the team composition to increase the feasibility of the project." - We have a team member with 7 years of experience in teaching and translating in Vietnam. If you have ever been involved in translation work, you will know that on average 1 translator can translate 100 pages (300 words/page)/day (in 8 working hours). Therefore, 370 pages translated in 1 month ~13 pages/day is feasible.

Auditability: I agree with you that the number of downloads on google drive can be faked. But it's like youtube views, likes, comments. You can also fake those parameters. But it's not because we're skeptical that we can't measure the success of a proposal by those criteria because it's easy to fake. We still have to use the number of downloads, views, and likes to know if the document or video is successful or not. 
In addition, we also have other indicators such as: The number of developers participating in the Plutus Pioneer course can be measured by registration forms.
The number of proposals submitted on Catalyst can be checked by "Has someone referred you to become a proposer?"

f6_assessments.q0:
Cardano is built on Haskell and it is an uncommon programming language in most parts of the world. This is a proposal to translate the highly recommended book by Charles Hoskinson and IOHK, “Learn you a Haskell for Great Good”, into Japanese; this effectively addresses the challenge by making the knowledge of Haskell more accessible to a non-english speaking country.

The project proposer states that Japan is one of the countries with a large number of developers, but has limited access to Blockchain and Smart Contract documentations because English is a huge barrier for them. If the book is successfully translated, I believe this project wins two-fold, it will bring new developers into the ecosystem and achieve diversity in the developer ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
The book “Learn you a Haskell for Great Good” can be read in English for free at http://learnyouahaskell.com/ and is licensed under a creative commons license. The proposer is not the author but is free to share and adapt the book as long as it is for non-commercial purposes. There are no legal concerns that will arise out of this project.

The team is asking a sum of USD$9,250 - $25 per page for the 370-pages book.

The team consists of a dynamic duo: 
A Haskell developer with 5 years of Haskell programming experience. He has an existing 2-year-old YouTube channel that teaches mainly Haskell; and 
a Japanese interpreter who has 10 years experience translating and interpreting Japanese with 2 years experience experience evaluating blockchain projects. 

It is reassuring to see that the team already has experience in educating Haskell so there is no doubt this proposal will be implemented successfully.

Neither Agree nor Disagree

The timeline of this project is 3 months. The proposer aims to complete the translation of the book within a month and then disseminate the book to the Japanese developer community in the 2nd and 3rd month. 

The milestones are clearly laid:
Complete Japanese translation of the book Learn You a Haskell for Great Good
Reached 500 downloads in the first 3 months
10 developers join the Plutus Pioneer Program
5 proposals from developers in Japan submitted to Catalyst
  The goals to reach 500 downloads is highly likely and the developers joining the Plutus Pioneer Program and submitting proposals to Catalyst will also likely follow, however my biggest concern is the timeframe for translation seemed a bit too optimistic. The team only has 1 translator and the timeline suggests that 12 pages will be translated per day. Considering that this is not an everyday translation but a technical one, I believe more time is needed for the translation - a 2-3 month timeframe is more likely for translating the book.

f6_assessments.q0:
I have been working as a developer for more than 5 years. My English is also not at the level I want it to be. However, I do not think it is a good idea to translate and read technical books in other languages. It is better to be created English language courses for Japanese developers who do not understand the language than reading the text in another language. I have two books in my native language and I have not completely read both because there are translated terms that should not be translated.
If the translation will be made, I strongly recommend that technical terms not be translated. This means that most of the book will not be translated. The explanations and algorithms will be translated, which will be great.
Still, in my opinion, it seems more useful to do Japanese courses about the book, with the teacher being technically literate. These courses can be only the first step to the Cardano ecosystem. After that, more advanced courses can be created
f6_assessments.q1:
The translation of the book to be done in one month sounds absolutely achievable. 200 downloads should not be a problem either, since the book will be free, every developer in Japan will want to see it. But how many of these developers will really start dealing with Haskell? And how many of them will enter the Cardano ecosystem? There should be a more detailed study here for developers who want to learn Haskell and enter the Cardano ecosystem. Maybe it would be good to make 10 publications in advance in the respective communities. If the programmers point to the language barrier and the lack of Haskell training as the main problem, then this translation will be extremely necessary.
It is very good that the translators are a technical person and a person with 10 years of experience with translations and is part of the Cardano ecosystem. Without a technical person, quality translation will be impossible. If they are approved, I do not think they will have any problems with quality translation. As I said above, I would recommend that the terms remain in English.
The budget absolutely corresponds to the work that will be done by a programmer with 5 years of experience and a professional translator.
f6_assessments.q2:
The plan is good, but there seems to be no further study and explanation of the numbers.
Why exactly in 3 months? How exactly are 500 downloads calculated? 10 people out of 500 downloads are 2% of the people who downloaded the book to join the Plutus Pioneer Program. Why exactly 2%?
In my opinion, it would be a good idea to have a marketing plan in place or to introduce people to the Plutus Pioneer Program and Catalyst. Or the book must come with an obligation - to download it you need to register in the Plutus Pioneer Program.
It is not entirely clear why these goals were set and how exactly they will be achieved.
f6_assessments.reply:
Thank you very much for taking the time to assess our proposal

Impact: If you are a Japanese who does not know English you will know why we have to translate these books into English. People who only know the language of their country of study actually face a language barrier when accessing books in English. It is possible that a book translated into Japanese cannot represent 100% of the book in English. But 95% of the knowledge in these books is completely understandable without problems (there may be some concepts that are not found in the Japanese language). Therefore, when we translate terms, we explain them in a way that is easy to understand. Example Tuples: Is a list type whose elements can be of different types (a, b). a :: Number. b:: Char.

Auditability: We chose those target numbers based on the communities we interacted with, and those are the target numbers we want to work towards. Why 2%? That is the goal we want to achieve. And that number is achievable
"Or the book must come with an obligation - to download it you need to register in the Plutus Pioneer Program." - You can only register in the Plutus Pioneer Program when the IOHK form opens. This will limit the number of people who can access this book.
